channel.title: NYT > Arts
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘Stranger Things’ Cast Looks Back on the Show and How It Shaped Them
item.description: The first episodes of the final season just premiered on Netflix. In interviews, the young stars looked back on the show and how it shaped them.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Egner, Alexis Soloski and Chantal Anderson
item.media:credit: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times

item.title: 5 Years After His Death, John Prine Gets a Cinematic Send-Off
item.description: The singer and songwriter died in April 2020 of Covid-19, delaying proper tributes. Now he is the subject of a new documentary, “You Got Gold.”
item.dc:creator: Bob Mehr
item.category: You Got Gold: A Celebration of John Prine (Movie)
item.media:description: John Prine in 1975. A profound sense of intimacy was the hallmark of his work.

item.title: ‘Blossoms Shanghai’ Review: In the Mood for Commerce
item.description: Wong Kar-wai’s first TV series, streaming on the Criterion Channel, is a lush melodrama about an economic miracle.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale
item.media:description: Hu Ge stars as the Gatsby-like protagonist of “Blossoms Shanghai,” the first television series from Wong Kar-wai.

item.title: ‘BLKNWS: Terms & Conditions’ Review: An Artist’s Mind-Expanding Collage
item.description: In this dazzling essay movie, the director Kahlil Joseph draws on an array of sources — news clips, old movies, family albums, an encyclopedia of ”Africana” — to create a thrilling whole.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Jimmy Fallon Gets Into the Spirit of ‘Drinksgiving’
item.description: “’Twas the night before Thanksgiving, and in your parents’ house, they put the Peloton in your old bedroom, so you’re sleeping on the couch,” Fallon mused.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: A Speedy Art-Career Rise Fueled by a Descent Into Our Modern Abyss
item.description: Contemporary life, speculative fiction, Asian futurism and social documentary all meet in Ayoung Kim’s videos at MoMA PS1. And are they fun to watch!
item.dc:creator: Martha Schwendener

item.title: Louvre Raising Ticket Prices for Non-European Visitors
item.description: From Jan. 14, visitors to the museum from outside the European Economic Area will pay 45 percent more for entry to help finance its ambitious renovation plan.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic and Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Louvre is still on the mend after thieves broke into one of its galleries in October and stole about $100 million worth of jewelry.

item.title: A Guide to N.Y.C. Holiday Events: Music, Lights and More
item.description: Matinees, ice skating and train shows: Here are some of our favorite things to do this season.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi
item.media:description: The reveal of Saks Fifth Avenue’s holiday light show and windows on Monday, Nov. 24.

item.title: At New York City Ballet’s ‘Nutcracker,’ Bring on Fritz and Brat Winter
item.description: At New York City Ballet, two boys from the School of American Ballet get to play a coveted role: Fritz, a terror of a little brother.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas and Thea Traff
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Thea Traff for The New York Times

item.title: How a Rediscovered Klimt Got Swept Up in an International Dispute
item.description: The Viennese painter’s portrait of a West African prince was owned by a Jewish family who fled the Nazi occupation. It was then taken to Hungary, which has now moved to block a sale by an Austrian gallery.
item.dc:creator: Scott Reyburn
item.media:credit: Marcel Van Hoorn/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Gustav Klimt painting of Prince William Nii Nortey Dowuona on display earlier this year.

item.title: Ruth Thorne-Thomsen, Photographer of Dreamlike Tableaux, Dies at 82
item.description: Using a pinhole camera, she captured miniature landscapes that she had fashioned to resemble surreal versions of 19th-century travel photos.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:description: Ruth Thorne-Thomsen in an undated photo. When a friend gave her a pinhole camera in graduate school, “I knew immediately that this was it,” she said. “It was the blueprint, the matrix, for everything that followed.”

item.title: Fatherhood on Film: Dad Is Having a Rough Time Onscreen This Season
item.description: In films like “One Battle After Another,” “Springsteen” and “Ella McCay,” patriarchs are depicted as emotionally stunted or worse.
item.dc:creator: Clarissa Cruz

item.title: Robert A.M. Stern, Architect Who Reinvented Prewar Splendor, Dies at 86
item.description: He designed museums, schools and libraries before winning international acclaim late in life for 15 Central Park West in Manhattan, hailed as a rebirth of the luxury apartment building.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:description: Robert A.M. Stern in 2007. Glowing reviews drove a stampede of celebrities to 15 CPW — the building he described as “my breakthrough” — overshadowing the competition from sleek glass towers that had been the rage in Manhattan early in the new millennium.

item.title: ‘You Got Gold: A Celebration of John Prine’ Review: Paying Tribute in Nashville
item.description: Lyle Lovett, Bonnie Raitt, Kacey Musgraves and other luminaries perform Prine’s songs in this engaging concert film.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: ‘The Thing With Feathers’ Review: Parenting Without Your Better Half
item.description: A grieving father struggles to care for his two children after the death of his wife. Even with its star, Benedict Cumberbatch, the movie never takes flight.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: ‘The Stringer: The Man Who Took the Photo’ Review: Freelancing Woes
item.description: Was a freelance photographer intentionally left out of the famous Vietnam War photo of “Napalm Girl”?
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza
item.category: The Stringer: The Man Who Took the Photo (Movie)

item.title: ‘Left-Handed Girl’ Review: An Electric Portrait of Taipei
item.description: The filmmaker Shih-Ching Tsou tells a sensitive story of a mother and her two daughters struggling to get by in Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: 3 Cozy Books We Love
item.description: Pick up a mug of tea, grab a blanket and settle down to read. Jennifer Harlan, an editor at The New York Times Book Review, recommends three books that are perfect for cozy fall reading.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Harlan, Karen Hanley, Claire Hogan and Laura Salaberry

item.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘No Hugging … and Definitely Nothing Lewd’
item.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.

item.title: Broadway Performers Rehearse for the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade
item.description: We tagged along to a late-night rehearsal for performers from “Just in Time,” “Buena Vista Social Club” and “Ragtime.”
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg and Dolly Faibyshev
item.media:credit: Dolly Faibyshev for The New York Times

item.title: ‘The Secret Agent’ Review: Wagner Moura Is on the Run
item.description: Wagner Moura takes cover in this knockout from the filmmaker Kleber Mendonça Filho that is largely set in 1977 during Brazil’s miliary dictatorship.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Apple TV Series ‘The Hunt’ Is Pulled Amid Accusations of Plagiarism
item.description: Apple TV postponed the launch of the French-language series following accusations that its creator copied key elements from a 1973 novel.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: The French screenwriter Cédric Anger, who wrote “The Hunt,” pictured in Los Angeles in October.

item.title: A Therapist’s Advice on How to Navigate the Holiday Season With Family
item.description: Family holidays can be stressful. They don’t have to be.
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin

item.title: How Jane Austen Fans Are Celebrating Her 250th Birthday
item.description: For Janeites around the globe, the 250th anniversary of the English author’s birth is cause for elaborate celebrations.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.category: Austen, Jane, Society of North America
Jane Austen Society of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Peter Flude for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Zootopia 2’ Review: Natural Habitats, Expanded
item.description: A sequel to the 2016 hit, this movie about an animal metropolis takes on an even messier social allegory than the first one, while building out a wider (if bloated) universe.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: ‘Teenage Wasteland’ Review: Young in Age, Mature in Reporting
item.description: This documentary looks back at a group of teenagers who, in the early 1990s, created a high school video project that ended up breaking real news.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Hamnet’ Review: The Rest Is Silence
item.description: Jessie Buckley and Paul Mescal star in a heartbreaking adaptation of the best-selling novel.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Eternity’ Review: Dead Reckoning
item.description: Elizabeth Olsen plays a dead woman who must choose her forever partner in this silly afterlife rom-com.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: ‘Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery’ Review: Forgive Them, Father
item.description: Josh O’Connor leads a star-studded cast in the latest Benoit Blanc mystery — this one, about religious cults of personality.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)

item.title: June Leaf Made Art Like a Mad Scientist, a Dancer, an Aviator and an Archer
item.description: Endlessly energetic, the sculptor, who died last year, was often overshadowed by her famous husband, Robert Frank. But the Grey Art Museum brings her to the foreground.
item.dc:creator: Jillian Steinhauer

item.title: Her Face Is on a Nigerian Bank Note. But Her Work Is Rarely Seen.
item.description: A show focused on Ladi Kwali and other Black female potters at the Ford Foundation Gallery is a revelation.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.category: Body Vessel Clay: Black Women, Ceramics & Contemporary Art (Exhibit)

item.title: 15 New Books to Read in December: Olga Tokarczuk, John Darnielle, Olivia Nuzzi and More
item.description: New novels by Olga Tokarczuk and Kamilah Cole, nonfiction by John Darnielle and Olivia Nuzzi, a Booker Prize finalist and more.

item.title: Seth Meyers Bastes Trump for His Rambling Turkey Pardon
item.description: The president spent so much time talking that Meyers thinks the turkeys would have preferred to be put out of their misery.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: 5 New Art Parks You Must See
item.description: Five destinations, whether in the English countryside or a forest in Thailand, where the work and nature go hand in hand.
item.dc:creator: Gisela Williams
item.category: Srihatta-Samdani Art Centre and Sculpture Park (Sylhet, Bangladesh)
Goodwood Art Foundation (West Sussex, England, Museum)
Khao Yai Art Forest (Khao Yai, Thailand, Museum)

item.title: 8 New Songs You Should Hear Now
item.description: Catch up on recent releases from Robyn, Oneohtrix Point Never, Mavis Staples and more.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz

item.title: Review: A Revolution Without Poetry in the Met Opera’s ‘Chénier’
item.description: Umberto Giordano’s tragedy of love undone by the French Revolution has returned, but as an evening of coarse music making.
item.dc:creator: Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
item.media:description: Sonya Yoncheva, left, and Piotr Beczala in “Andrea Chénier” at the Metropolitan Opera.

item.title: What to Remember From ‘Stranger Things’ Before Season 5 Premieres
item.description: Over three years have passed since Season 4 of the hit Netflix series, and the ultimate showdown is finally here. Here’s where the young heroes left off.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray
item.media:description: Eleven (Millie Bobby Brown, with David Harbour) is back for one final battle with the creatures of the Upside Down, in Season 5 of “Stranger Things.”

item.title: Equal Parts Baroque and R&B, John Holiday Is His Own Singer
item.description: Holiday, a countertenor, has forged a career that blends classical repertoire and his upbringing in church and pop music.
item.dc:creator: Oussama Zahr
item.media:credit: Jared Soares for The New York Times
item.media:description: The countertenor John Holiday, whose season includes performances of works by Handel and Philip Glass.

item.title: 45 Years of Rock ’n’ Roll Theater at St. Ann’s Warehouse
item.description: In shows like “Black Watch,” “The Jungle” and “Oklahoma!,” the institution has affirmed the theater’s singular power to shock and illuminate our world.
item.dc:creator: Ben Brantley
item.media:credit: Richard Termine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Willem Dafoe (on the floor) and Ari Fliakos in the Wooster Group’s “To You, the Birdie!,” an adaptation of Racine’s “Phèdre,” at St. Ann’s Warehouse in 2002.

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel Is Charmed by the Trump-Mamdani Bromance
item.description: “What a turn of events!” Kimmel said of the president’s warm words for New York’s mayor-elect. “It was like he was giving a wedding toast to his new son-in-law.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Real Time With Bill Maher (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Thomas King, Award-Winning Canadian Author, Says He Is Not Indigenous
item.description: Thomas King said he felt “ripped in half” on learning he had no Indigenous ancestry. The Canadian author has dedicated his career to writing about Indigenous people.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.media:description: Thomas King posing for a portrait in 2012.

item.title: Udo Kier, Familiar Movie Villain and Fixture of the Offbeat, Dies at 81
item.description: A German-born actor, he appeared in more than 280 films, from Hollywood action fare to a Warhol horror tale. Madonna liked him for her videos.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:description: Udo Kier in a scene from Gus Van Sant’s “My Own Private Idaho” (1991). He gravitated to transgressive fare.

item.title: With Tom Felton, ‘Harry Potter’ Breaks Its Own Broadway Record
item.description: The actor is now playing an adult version of the sinister child he portrayed in the film series.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.category: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child (Play)
item.media:description: Tom Felton, left, as Draco Malfoy and John Skelley as Harry Potter in “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child” at the Lyric Theater.

item.title: ‘Queen of Versailles’ to Close as New Broadway Musicals Struggle
item.description: The show, starring Kristin Chenoweth, will remain open through the holidays. The announcement comes just two weeks after the musical opened.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: Kristin Chenoweth in “The Queen of Versailles” at the St. James Theater.

item.title: Jimmy Cliff Brought Reggae to the Masses with ‘The Harder They Come’
item.description: The 1972 film “The Harder They Come” and its accompanying soundtrack brought the genre out of Jamaica and helped pave the way for future stars.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams
item.media:description: The soundtrack to “The Harder They Come,” featuring several Jimmy Cliff songs, is one of reggae’s most important recordings.

item.title: At the NY Phil, Considering the American Character in 2 Violin Concertos
item.description: At the New York Philharmonic, concertos by Samuel Barber and Wynton Marsalis offered contrasting musical ideas: lyrical cohesion and vibrant pluralism.
item.dc:creator: Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim

item.title: Wen Hui Was Making Feminist Art Before She Even Knew the Term
item.description: The Chinese dancer, choreographer and filmmaker “didn’t think in those terms” when she was young. Now, she said, “I’m more relaxed, more clear on what I want to do.”
item.dc:creator: Rebecca L. Davis
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: in 1994, Ms. Wen founded Living Dance Studio, China’s first independent dance theater group.

item.title: Jimmy Cliff: 8 Essential Songs
item.description: A giant of Jamaican music, he gained international renown through the 1972 film “The Harder They Come,” and helped establish reggae’s themes of struggle, resistance and uplift.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: Jimmy Cliff onstage in 2013. The Jamaican musician helped transform ska into reggae, and bring his island’s sounds worldwide.

item.title: At 95, David Amram Still Makes Music. And Nobody Can Put Him in a Box.
item.description: Jazz, classical, folk, world music — for this composer, categories were never confining.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles and Erik Tanner
item.media:credit: Erik Tanner for The New York Times

item.title: Alma Allen, American Sculptor, Is Selected for Venice Biennale
item.description: The choice of a relatively unknown artist based in Mexico City ends a chaotic, much-delayed selection process led by the State Department.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small
item.category: Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs
item.media:credit: Jake Naughton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The artist Alma Allen, 55, will exhibit nearly 30 sculptures at the U.S. pavilion of the 2026 Venice Biennale starting in May, organized by the curator Jeffrey Uslip. Allen lives and works in Mexico.

item.title: This ‘All My Sons’ Is Tragedy Done Right
item.description: Arthur Miller and Ivo van Hove are a perfect match again, in a new production starring Bryan Cranston and Paapa Essiedu.
item.dc:creator: Houman Barekat

item.title: Jimmy Cliff, Singer Who Helped Bring Reggae to Global Audience, Dies at 81
item.description: His Grammy-winning records as well as his starring role in the cult movie “The Harder They Come” in 1972 boosted a career spanning seven decades.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall and Alex Williams
item.media:description: Jimmy Cliff performing in Le Castellet, France, in 1976.

item.title: In a $2.2 Billion Week, the Art Market Finds Its Footing
item.description: After years of declining sales, records set from major collections (Klimt, Kahlo) primed the auction houses for a rebound at the top.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small, Julia Halperin and Tim F. Schneider

item.title: His Right Foot: One Tiny Drawing for Sale, Said to Be by Michelangelo
item.description: The Renaissance artist painted more than 100 figures in the Sistine Chapel ceiling, yet studies for only a handful remain. Could this five-inch drawing at Christie’s be one?
item.dc:creator: Scott Reyburn
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Various books and research materials at Christie’s in London related to a newly attributed drawing the auction house says is by Michelangelo that is for sale in February.

item.title: ‘Jazz Island’ at Ailey Will Revive an Old-School Theatrical Style
item.description: Maija García’s “Jazz Island” is a full-company narrative of a kind that Ailey hasn’t done in a while. And it features an Afro-Caribbean score by Etienne Charles.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times

item.title: Ted Danson and Mary Steenburgen Star in a Love Story, Onscreen and Off
item.description: Married for three decades, the actors get together as characters in the second season of “A Man on the Inside.”
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski and Sela Shiloni
item.category: A Man on the Inside (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Sela Shiloni for The New York Times

item.title: What Historical Feuds and Onscreen Squabbles Can Teach Us About Our Obsession With Revenge
item.description: From Washington to Hollywood, American culture is now defined by score settling. But what do centuries of feuding have to teach us about getting even?
item.dc:creator: Mark Harris, M.H. Miller and Minju Pak

item.title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Musicals
item.description: Andrew Lloyd Webber, Sara Bareilles, Joshua Henry, Jeanine Tesori, Jason Robert Brown and New York Times writers and editors pick 13 songs to seal the deal.
item.category: Sit Down, Youre Rocking the Boat (Song)
Theres a Boat Thats Leavin Soon for New York (Song)
And I Am Telling You Im Not Going (Song)

item.title: How ‘Everybody Loves Raymond’ Brought My Mother and Me Closer
item.description: The show wasn’t an obvious draw for a Bengali immigrant and her teenage son. But the characters’ needs were things we needed, too.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.media:description: Doris Roberts and Ray Romano in “Everybody Loves Raymond.” A 30th anniversary special airs on CBS on Monday night.
